items.title: How to download the benchmark files before run a test?
items.body:

[INFO] Downloading data for track nyc_taxis (4.5 GB total size)                   [  1.8%]
[ERROR] Cannot race. Error in track preparator (HTTPConnectionPool(host='benchmarks.elasticsearch.org.s3.amazonaws.com', port=80): Read timed out.)

items.body:
**Rally version** (get with `esrally --version`): `2.0.0`

**Invoked command**: `sudo ./esrally-dist-2.0.0/install.sh`

**Configuration file (located in `~/.rally/rally.ini`))**:

**JVM version**: not installed 

**OS version**: CentOS 7

**Description of the problem including expected versus actual behavior**:

**Steps to reproduce**:
 1.Follow steps 1 - 4 in the Offline Install [guide](https://esrally.readthedocs.io/en/stable/install.html#offline-install)
 2. Step 4 results in the following events
 
```
$ sudo ./esrally-dist-2.0.0/install.sh
[sudo] password for eddie:
Installing Rally 2.0.0...
Python3 is required but not installed.
```

I suspect the install aborted because Python3 is not installed but it might make sense to be more explicit in what the outcome was. If the install did abort, maybe say "Install aborted due to Python3 being required but no installation located".

items.title: Evaluate effort to upgrade to elasticsearch-py 7.7.0
items.body:
elasticsearch-py 7.7.0 brings EQL support and https://github.com/elastic/rally/pull/1014 attempted to bump the version of the library used by Rally.

However, as mentioned in https://github.com/elastic/rally/pull/1014#issuecomment-643245590, upgrading might not be straightforward due a number of reasons:

1. Rally relies heavily on [elasticsearch-async](https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch-py-async); since this dependency got introduced, the standard elasticsearch-py library received [async support](https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch-py/pull/1232/files) and async development/maintenance mored there.

For elasticsearch-async we had to implement several abstractions and workarounds due to missing features or bugs (e.g. [here](https://github.com/elastic/rally/blob/6961f87a20e9927cd0c442c13e99b52a4179ba8b/esrally/client.py#L170-L214) and [here](https://github.com/elastic/rally/blob/6961f87a20e9927cd0c442c13e99b52a4179ba8b/esrally/async_connection.py#L28-L155)).

This ticket will evaluate the safety of upgrading the elasticsearch-py dependency from: https://github.com/elastic/rally/blob/6961f87a20e9927cd0c442c13e99b52a4179ba8b/setup.py#L52 to `7.7.0`.

items.title: Clarify that indexing related sections are not required in a track
items.body:
Background: https://discuss.elastic.co/t/rally-custom-benchmark-only-pipeline-track-without-corpora/231878?u=dliappis

We should clarify that the [track sections](https://esrally.readthedocs.io/en/stable/track.html#anatomy-of-a-track) `indices`, `corpora`, `templates` are not required, thus a query-only track can be used as shown in [this example](https://esrally.readthedocs.io/en/stable/track.html#a-track-with-a-single-task).

items.title: Don't preserve OS's JAVA*_HOME vars before launching Elasticsearch
items.body:
## Description

When user specifies `--runtime-jdk=bundled` if `JAVA_HOME` is already set then it remains present and honored by Elasticsearch thus preferring `JAVA_HOME` than the bundled jdk (for versions of Elasticsearch coming with a bundled jdk of course)

Instead Rally should unset all JAVA*_HOME vars, specifically `JAVA_HOME`, but also `JAVA{7,8,9,10,11,...}_HOME` as a precaution for the future too.

While at it, let's also fix the weird indentation in https://github.com/elastic/rally/blob/635757e4ff70227c976febbdfeca582c6cb6a944/esrally/mechanic/launcher.py#L192 and https://github.com/elastic/rally/blob/635757e4ff70227c976febbdfeca582c6cb6a944/esrally/mechanic/launcher.py#L194

items.title: Migrate all integration tests to new infrastructure
items.body:
In https://github.com/elastic/rally/pull/919 we added a new integration test infrastructure based on `py.test` to replace the existing shell script `integration-test.sh`. While some of the integration tests have already been migrated, a couple of them are still left:

* [x] `test_proxy_connection` https://github.com/elastic/rally/pull/1029
* [x] `test_configure` #1023
* [x] `test_distribution_fails_with_wrong_track_params`: https://github.com/elastic/rally/pull/977
* [x] `test_docker_dev_image` #1026 
* [x] Remove `integration-test.sh` and its invocation in `tox.ini` https://github.com/elastic/rally/pull/1029

items.title: Don't use a network range for [http|transport].port when installing Elasticsearch
items.body:
The new [install subcommand](https://esrally.readthedocs.io/en/stable/command_line_reference.html#install) uses a range for `http.port` and `transport.tcp.port` (e.g. `http.port: 39200-39300`) even if the port is specified with `--http-port`.

We should be less lenient and configure these two properties in `elasticsearch.yml` without ranges.

items.title: Externalize number of tries until es rest api is availiable parameter
items.body: as pointed out [here](https://discuss.elastic.co/t/unable-to-increase-rest-api-startup-timeout/221719) there is no way to alter the number of tries we attempt to contact ES to make sure the cluster is online, nor the sleep time between each wait. It would make sense to externalize one of these, I think.

items.title: [Feature request] Handle running processes automatically with a explicit flag
items.body:
When I run esrally with default settings (i.e --on-error=continue), I can 'cancel' the esrally process using `CTRL+C` in my terminal. Maybe I would like to make a change and restart esrally.

The problem is: the next time I run esrally, it won't be able to start a race because of the old esrally process:
```
    ____        ____
   / __ \____ _/ / /_  __
  / /_/ / __ `/ / / / / /
 / _, _/ /_/ / / / /_/ /
/_/ |_|\__,_/_/_/\__, /
                /____/

[ERROR] Cannot race. There are other Rally processes running on this machine (PIDs: [4122, 4123, 4124, 4172, 4234, 4235]) but only one Rally benchmark is allowed to run at the same time. Please check and terminate these processes and retry again.

Getting further help:
*********************
* Check the log files in /home/vitor/.rally/logs for errors.
* Read the documentation at https://esrally.readthedocs.io/en/1.4.0/
* Ask a question on the forum at https://discuss.elastic.co/c/elasticsearch/rally
* Raise an issue at https://github.com/elastic/rally/issues and include the log files in /home/vitor/.rally/logs.

-------------------------------
[INFO] FAILURE (took 0 seconds)
-------------------------------
```

Steps to reproduce:

1. Run `esrally --distribution-version=7.6.0 --track percolator`
2. In your terminal, cancel the command with `CTRL+C`
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18057391/75631570-c71c4580-5bd2-11ea-89ea-c490e0e140f0.png)

3. Try to run `esrally --distribution-version=7.6.0 --track percolator` again.
4. You will see another processes running in background. You need to manually kill them.

This issue is to suggest a flag in esrally that could kill automatically these running process to help the usability. The default could be the warning with a flag suggestion, something like `--kill-running-process` or something to automatically deal with it.

I'm not sure if this is appropriate feature to have in esrally or if the processes are entirely controlable by the SO.

items.title: Add telemetry for Safepoint statistics
items.body: JVM Safepoints can cause pauses + jitter in benchmarks and without any telemetry they are difficult to thoroughly investigate.

items.title: Warn on request errors
items.body:
By default Rally continues on request errors (`--on-error=continue`) but this might be easy to miss by users. In addition, some operations are treated as "administrative" (e.g. `create-index`) and are thus not included in the command line report by default. We should:

1. Include any operations with an error rate greater than zero in the command line report regardless whether they should be included (see https://github.com/elastic/rally/blob/97d0e85ab0cffd1f1506af96aee1e4a69310fc2a/esrally/metrics.py#L1631)
2. Emit a warning when the error rate of an operation is greater than zero (in https://github.com/elastic/rally/blob/97d0e85ab0cffd1f1506af96aee1e4a69310fc2a/esrally/reporter.py#L134)

items.title: Race condition in wait_for_pidfile()
items.body: As seen recently in the CI build for #899 (https://elasticsearch-ci.elastic.co/job/elastic+rally+pull-request/114/console), there is a tiny gap between file-create and file-write for the pidfile that can break our pidfile-reading code.  We should be more resilient in this situation.

items.title: Release Rally 1.4.1
items.body:
We should release Rally `1.4.1`.

The process is defined in https://github.com/elastic/rally/blob/master/RELEASE.md and [preconditions](https://github.com/elastic/rally/blob/master/RELEASE.md#preconditions) and [initial setup](https://github.com/elastic/rally/blob/master/RELEASE.md#initial-setup) need to be met/done before initiating the release.

Target date: 20200218 (Wed Feb 19 2020 15:00 UTC)

items.title: Rally silently ignores errors when creating an index
items.body: If a challenge includes an invalid body for the index creation call, Rally seems to silently ignore the error, and the index then gets created implicitly via the first bulk request.

items.title: Use zeroes instead of whitespaces as padding bytes
items.body: When generating ids for conflicts, rally uses spaces as padding bytes. I rarely see spaces in ids, so I think this is less realistic than using zeroes? Furthermore Elasticsearch has some optimizations for ids that look like base64 or numeric ids, which get defeated by the usage of spaces.

items.title: More descriptive output of `esrallyd status`
items.body:
Would it be possible to have the output of `esrallyd status` be more descriptive?

Right now it appears to just check if a port is open, it'd be helpful if it could describe the actors associated with the rally cluster.

e.g. associated IPs of load drivers and the coordinator for example.

This makes it hard to figure out what went wrong inside https://github.com/elastic/rally/blob/21347e1504618ef215f4795b86f1a4614f7d2ea2/integration-test.sh#L502-L535.

Maybe an easy fix is possible, e.g. using and `set -xo pipefail` before at the beginning of the function.

items.title: Check for presence of `docker-compose` in IT tests
items.body:
IT tests require `docker-compose`.

Let's make sure IT tests fail early if `docker-compose` is not present.

items.title: Private custom track repository and corpora URLs
items.body:
**Describe the feature**:
It's impossible, with offline mode, tu use custom repository for tracks without cloning manually or download custom corpora on private repo though these repositories are accessibles. It would be great if custom repository are cloned even in offline mode.  
It would also be a nice addition to allow custom probing URLfor internet connection, thus in an environment where things like elasticsearch sources, corpora, ...etc are mirrored and provided that one configure properly the rally.ini file, it is possible to run rally in online mode.

items.title: Clarify the impact on refreshes for node-stats telemetry
items.body:
In the [docs of the node stats telemetry device](https://esrally.readthedocs.io/en/stable/telemetry.html#node-stats) we state:

> Using this telemetry device will skew your results because the node-stats API triggers additional refreshes. Additionally a lot of metrics get recorded impacting the measurement results even further.

Furthermore, when this telemetry device is used, we issue the following warning:

> [WARNING] You have enabled the node-stats telemetry device, but requests to the _nodes/stats Elasticsearch endpoint trigger additional refreshes and WILL SKEW results.

This is only the case before Elasticsearch 7.2 and has been fixed with https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/pull/40458. Therefore we should clarify that this only applies to Elasticsearch before 7.2 and maybe issue the warning also only for versions before 7.2.

**Describe the feature**:

Getting further help:

items.title: Update force-merge operation to only force-merge track specific indices
items.body:
It looks like the existing force-merge operation by default performs a force-merge on all indices by passing "_all" as the index parameter. It might be better to scope this to only the indices created by the current rally track, or allow the user to specify a specific index to force-merge, similar to how other operations like delete-index currently work. 

It seems like it should be a fairly minor change, and I can submit a pull request for this if this sounds good.

items.title: Fail when distribution-version is used together with benchmark-only pipeline
items.body:
As described in https://discuss.elastic.co/t/elasticsearch-rest-api-layer-is-not-available-forcefully-terminated-cluster/209239/4, seems it would be beneficial for users to prohibit the user of `--distribution-version` together with the `benchmark-only` pipeline.

If we don't want to go down that path due to #722 , at least we can clarify this in the docs [here](https://esrally.readthedocs.io/en/stable/command_line_reference.html#distribution-version).

items.title: The URL require username and password to login!
items.body:
The URL of installation of Python for RHEL / CentOS 6 and 7 require username and password to login!

RHEL / CentOS 6 and 7

Please refer to the [installation instructions for Python 3.5 in the Red Hat Software Collections.](https://www.softwarecollections.org/en/scls/rhscl/rh-python35/)

items.title: Rally docker tests use port 9200
items.body: The rally docker tests use the default elasticsearch port instead of a random or known nonstandard port. this should be updated so that it does not use 9200 as that can collide with existing es instances locally.

items.title: Document how to escape Mustache expressions in tracks
items.body: If a user wants to use Mustache expresssions in their Rally tracks (e.g. because they want to [use Watcher](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/7.4/actions-email.html) or [search templates](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/7.4/search-template.html)), they run into trouble, because each Rally track is actually a Jinja template and thus this expression will be treated as Jinja template expression. Therefore, they need to be [escaped](https://jinja.palletsprojects.com/en/2.10.x/templates/#escaping) using `{% raw %}...{% endraw %}` but this is not obvious. We should therefore add an example to our track reference.

items.title: Version check error message is misleading
items.body:
At https://github.com/elastic/rally/blob/master/esrally/racecontrol.py#L200, we notify the user that a distribution version must be provided when we have failed to get the version by connecting to the cluster.  
If Rally cannot connect to the cluster with the information provided, supplying a version will not help the situation.  We should have a more helpful error message in this situation.

items.title: Running Rally with Python 3.8
items.body:
Python 3.8 was released on [Oct 14 2019](https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/3.8.html).

This ticket tracks:

- [x] evaluating compatibility with Python 3.8
- [x] identifying necessary changes (depending on issues identified) to support 3.8

items.title: Allow to use the bundled JDK for Rally-managed nodes
items.body: So far Rally will always download an Elasticsearch version with a bundled JDK (if the distribution contains one) but will explicitly set `JAVA_HOME` when launching a node thus the bundled JDK will never be used for benchmarks. We should investigate how we can allow users to use the bundled JDK (with a command line flag?) and void setting `JAVA_HOME` in any case.

items.title: restore-snapshot operation missing body parameter
items.body:
The [restore-snapshot operation](https://esrally.readthedocs.io/en/latest/track.html#restore-snapshot) introduced in #793 lacks the `body` property (which exists e.g. in [create-repository](https://esrally.readthedocs.io/en/latest/track.html#create-snapshot-repository)).

This property is optionally needed to control additional attributes of the [restore process](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/modules-snapshots.html#restore-snapshot) such as which indices to include, whether to include global state etc.

items.title: IndicesRecovery runner runs with 1 iteration and ends abruptly
items.body:
The new `IndicesRecovery` runner introduced in #793 (used by the [wait-for-recovery](https://esrally.readthedocs.io/en/latest/track.html#wait-for-recovery) operation) seems to use an iteration-count based schedule with 1 iteration. As a result it runs once, (calculates [percent_completed](https://github.com/elastic/rally/blob/a05207f7d63be6decdcc071905ce1e69c91b8b0f/esrally/driver/runner.py#L1197-L1198) correctly) and ends due to the schedule. Logs show:

> Creating iteration-count based schedule with [deterministic] distribution for [wait-for-recovery] with [0] warmup iterations and [1] iterations.

My understanding is that since we don't specify `iterations` or `warmup_iterations`, based on [#requires_time_period_schedule](https://github.com/elastic/rally/blob/a05207f7d63be6decdcc071905ce1e69c91b8b0f/esrally/driver/driver.py#L1398-L1405) which then sets [infinite=True](https://github.com/elastic/rally/blob/a05207f7d63be6decdcc071905ce1e69c91b8b0f/esrally/driver/driver.py#L1516-L1517) forcing 1 iteration in [#schedule_for](https://github.com/elastic/rally/blob/a05207f7d63be6decdcc071905ce1e69c91b8b0f/esrally/driver/driver.py#L1386-L1388).

Was it meant to be ran with a custom schedule?

Related: #789 and #763

items.title: Enforce coding conventions
items.body: We have existing conventions in the Rally code base (such that we should use double-quotes for strings and others) that we should start to enforce via a linter. The linter should be hooked into the build with a new `precommit` make target. The scope of this issue is to add the initial infrastructure but not to fix all violations. That should be done in follow-ups. Once this work is done, we should adopt a zero violation policy and fail the build on linter errors.

items.title: Calculate system metrics per node
items.body:
Rally captures not only request metrics (such as service time, latency and throughput) or cluster-wide metrics (such as GC times) but also system metrics per node (e.g. number of bytes written). Assuming an Elasticsearch metrics store, raw metrics are written to `rally-metrics`. When the node has been shutdown, the reporting component that is running on the coordinator node will then aggregate the raw results and store them in `rally-races` and `rally-results`.

With our move to a different execution model where nodes can be managed independently of the actual benchmark (see #697), this is not feasible anymore as there is no communication link between the `mechanic` managing individual nodes and the coordinator. Therefore, we need to aggregate per node metrics on each node. Consequently, these metrics will not be available in the command line report (because it might need to be displayed before the node is even shutdown as this will be coordinated by a component that is separate from Rally).

Subtasks:

* [x] Split calculation / aggregation of global and system metrics
* [x] Persist race-metadata early so they are available for enriching system metrics (at the end of a race)
* [x] Ensure we fallback gracefully with an in-memory metrics store (race metadata cannot be retrieved on remote nodes)
* [x] Adapt chart generator to use `sum` instead of `median` aggregation (there are now multiple samples - one per node - instead of one sample for system metrics)

items.title: Document an example how to extract HTTP responses during a Rally benchmark
items.body:
As part of developing a new search feature or optimization, I often run benchmarks by adding a new search operation to an existing rally track. I've found that it can be easy to make mistakes in setting up the benchmark:
* A few times I accidentally had an error in the search operation definition, for example I misspelled the name of the field or structured the query incorrectly. Both the contender and baseline were returning no results, but I simply thought my optimization wasn't working.
* Before benchmarking I write unit tests for the feature/ optimization in Elasticsearch. But it's still possible that I have an error in the search definitions so that the baseline and contender aren’t performing the same operation -- for example the contender could be returning a smaller result set.

For this use case, I wonder if it'd be useful for rally to return the number of hits from a search operation, or even the whole search response. Seeing that the baseline and contender return the same number of results (and return more than 0 results) would give confidence that I've set up the benchmark correctly and help avoid some manual testing.

items.title: Fix deprecations for ML-related runners with Elasticsearch 7.x
items.body:
When running our nightly benchmarks, we see several deprecation warnings in the logs:

```
[2019-09-25T09:31:31,988][WARN ][o.e.d.x.m.r.d.RestDeleteDatafeedAction] [rally-node-0] [DELETE /_xpack/ml/datafeeds/{datafeed_id}] is deprecated! Use [DELETE /_ml/datafeeds/{datafeed_id}] instead.
[2019-09-25T09:31:38,015][WARN ][o.e.d.x.m.r.j.RestDeleteJobAction] [rally-node-0] [DELETE /_xpack/ml/anomaly_detectors/{job_id}] is deprecated! Use [DELETE /_ml/anomaly_detectors/{job_id}] instead.
[2019-09-25T09:31:44,052][WARN ][o.e.d.x.m.r.j.RestPutJobAction] [rally-node-0] [PUT /_xpack/ml/anomaly_detectors/{job_id}] is deprecated! Use [PUT /_ml/anomaly_detectors/{job_id}] instead.
[2019-09-25T09:31:50,136][WARN ][o.e.d.x.m.r.j.RestOpenJobAction] [rally-node-0] [POST /_xpack/ml/anomaly_detectors/{job_id}/_open] is deprecated! Use [POST /_ml/anomaly_detectors/{job_id}/_open] instead.
[2019-09-25T09:31:56,170][WARN ][o.e.d.x.m.r.d.RestPutDatafeedAction] [rally-node-0] [PUT /_xpack/ml/datafeeds/{datafeed_id}] is deprecated! Use [PUT /_ml/datafeeds/{datafeed_id}] instead.
```

With https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/issues/35958, the `_xpack` path component in URLs is deprecated. To mitigate, we should:

* [x] Upgrade the Elasticsearch Python client (see #795)
* [ ] implement a fallback in all ML_related runners for versions for Elasticsearch before 7.0.0 (see `ForceMerge` for an example)

In https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/issues/36127 we discuss new network-related metrics that will be exposed by Elasticsearch. Once such an API is available, we should add a telemetry device in Rally that samples these metrics.

As that API is not yet available, I'm marking this issue as "blocked".

items.title: Support running sequence of queries as part of the search operation
items.body: Similar to #486 and the request to replay queries from the slow log (https://github.com/elastic/rally/issues/262#issuecomment-359829313), I think it would be awesome to pass a line-delimited file with all the queries that should be run and have Rally execute them.

items.title: Remove deprecated properties trial-id and trial-timestamp
items.body: With #778 we deprecate `trial-id` and `trial-timestamp` (which are written to `rally-*` indices in the metrics store) with Rally 1.4.0  in favor of `race-id` and `race-timestamp`. There is a BWC layer that allows users to still continue to use these properties but we should clean this up (see `TODO #777` comments in the code; in addition all mappings need to be cleaned up).

<!--

-->

**Rally version** (get with `esrally --version`): 1.2.1

**Invoked command**: 

`esrally --offline --target-hosts=https://<my_ip>:9200 --pipeline=benchmark-only --client-options="timeout:120,use_ssl:true,verify_certs --report-file=test-1.csv --track-path /mnt/rally/benchmarks/tracks/default/http_logs/`

**OS version**:

```
cat /etc/lsb-release
DISTRIB_ID=Ubuntu
DISTRIB_RELEASE=19.04
DISTRIB_CODENAME=disco
DISTRIB_DESCRIPTION="Ubuntu 19.04"
```

**Description of the problem including expected versus actual behavior**:

When using SSL options against a non-ssl endpoint, the error message is a bit cryptic as to what has failed.

```
[ERROR] Cannot race. Error in race control (ConnectionError([SSL: WRONG_VERSION_NUMBER] wrong version number (_ssl.c:1056)) caused by: SSLError([SSL: WRONG_VERSION_NUMBER] wrong version number (_ssl.c:1056)))
```

**Steps to reproduce**:

I saw this issue using `--client-options="timeout:120,use_ssl:true,verify_certs:false` against an endpoint with  `--target-hosts=https://whateverhost` 

Setting `use_ssl` to false and leaving verify_certs:false still saw the error occurring.
I had to remove the https and use http instead to have it correctly connect to the endpoint.

**Provide logs (if relevant)**:

**Describe the feature**:

A list of errors with possible causes/resolutions in a troubleshooting guide within the Rally docs is probably enough to steer users to the fix as I don't think this would be all that common.

Additionally, a more informative error message might give users the right hint faster (`"is this a https endpoint?"`)

items.title: [Feature Request] use compressed corpora directly
items.body:
Hi,

For some write-intense benchmarks, I run Rally with documents that are over 100GB in size. During the bulk requests stage, it seems that the client machine (i.e.: the one I run Rally) *cannot load documents fast enough*, because 100~200MB/s from a spinning-disk is the best it can offer 😅.

My current options to work around it:

1. run Rally on multiple machines in distributed mode (a little bit involved)
2. use SSD (but IO-optimized servers are in shortage in my environment)

So the feature request is: would it be possible for Rally to load documents from disk in *compressed* form? AFAIK gzip line-oriented file reading is well supported in Python.

Thanks!

items.title: Investigate moving integration tests to a more solid foundation
items.body:
We currently use a [shell script for our integration tests](https://github.com/elastic/rally/blob/b0c7b9378cc9c890c2973ea19df6797317e45eb3/integration-test.sh). This has several limitiations:

* We need to resort to adhoc solutions (e.g. we need Perl or require Docker for search / replace)
* Limited ability for assertions
* We cannot report test failures properly
* Hard to extend

We should instead investigate how we can properly support integration tests with Python (e.g. via py.test). 

Requirements:

* Should avoid all of the shorcomings above
* We should be able to run unit tests and integration tests separately. Ideally we can also clearly see in the source code structure which tests are unit tests and which ones are integration tests (separate root directories?)
* We should not rely on external tools such as Perl (note: Docker is required for Docker tests). Note: In order to reduce scope, we might want to port the existing tests first 1:1 and then improve them in follow-up PRs

items.title: Move unit-test JSON text into resources
items.body: Currently, JSON responses expected by unit tests are inline literals, which is making our python tests rather large.  We could reduce some unnecessary bulk by moving these responses into separate files.

items.title: Missing attach_to_node call for telemetry devices in DockerLauncher
items.body: We are missing a call to `attach_to_node` in DockerLauncher. It causes DiskIo telemetry device not to work correctly and missing data in metric store for bytes read and written.

items.title: [Feature Request] `esrallyd start` should not daemonize by default
items.body:
Currently `esrallyd start` daemonizes itself to background, which makes it difficult to run properly in Docker containers.

It would be great to add an CLI argument to opt-in / opt-out this behavior.

items.title: sysstats.py crashed if no valid brand string in cpuinfo on an eMAG aarch64 system
items.body:
**Rally version** (get with `esrally --version`):
1.1.0

**Invoked command**:
esrally --distribution-version=6.0.0

**Configuration file (located in `~/.rally/rally.ini`))**:
all default
datastore.type = in-memory

**JVM version**:
jdk1.8, the minor version does not matter

**OS version**:
CentOS 7.5

**Description of the problem including expected versus actual behavior**:
It is a very straightforward problem, the [py-cpuinfo](https://github.com/workhorsy/py-cpuinfo) tool cannot get a valid brand string from various system info or utilities on my aarch64 testing system. In theory, sysstats.py should handle this as a "Unknown" cpu model, at least. However, as "brand" is not a valid key in cpuinfo.get_cpu_info(), the test subsequently crashed and quit. A strict check as below has to be done.
 
https://github.com/elastic/rally/blob/4c160c8fbe7382f7db2af1d9c74c176f009029e5/esrally/utils/sysstats.py#L48
```
ci=cpuinfo.get_cpu_info()
return ci["brand"] if (cpuinfo_available and "brand" in ci) else "Unknown"
```
This issue was exposed and the quick fix has been verified fine on an Ampere Computing eMAG aarch64 system.

items.title: Ensure origin is elastic/rally before release
items.body: We should add a check that the origin remote points to elastic/rally before allowing a release, as scripts implicitly assume this is the case.

items.title: Drop support for Elasticsearch 1.x
items.body:
In order to reduce maintenance effort, we should stop supporting outdated versions of Elasticsearch. Elasticsearch 1.7 is end of life since January 2017 so we will drop support for it. We will take a couple of precautionary measures though:

* We will give users a clear indication what Rally version supports which Elasticsearch versions (see #714)
* While we will remove the respective branches also from rally-teams and rally-tracks, we will add a tag to effectively "freeze" the latest state. Rally will bring support to detect these tags and use them (see #713). This will allow users to switch to an older Rally version and still benchmark old Elasticsearch versions. 

Additional tasks:

* [x] Drop support in Rally: https://github.com/elastic/rally/pull/716
* [x] Drop support in rally-tracks: Pushed as tag `v1`: https://github.com/elastic/rally-tracks/tree/v1 (see also https://github.com/elastic/rally-tracks/issues/11)
* [x] Drop support in rally-teams: Pushed as tag `v1`: https://github.com/elastic/rally-teams/tree/v1

The latter two items have to be implemented by removing the branch `1` in the respective repos and adding a corresponding `v1` tag. Contrary to Rally, these changes are live "immediately" and thus would affect users. Therefore, we should aim for a grace period and remove the branches late in the release cycle for Rally 1.3.0.

items.title: Allow to manage Elasticsearch nodes separately from benchmarking
items.body:
Currently Rally can be used as a load generator and to manage Elasticsearch instances (building a distribution from sources, installing and configuring Elasticsearch as well as launching / stopping it). It is possible to use Rally as a standalone load generator (`--pipeline=benchmark-only`) but it is not possible to use Rally only to manage Elasticsearch nodes. In order to do that, we should allow to call the provisioning and launch phases as separate subcommands in Rally. We should only support a local mode though, i.e. it is not possible to only setup a cluster from the coordinator node but users must invoke Rally instead on each of the target nodes. As a corollary, each command  applies to only one node.

We will add the following subcommands:

* `provision`: Provisions a single node. The artefact might be built from sources or a distribution that has been downloaded.
* `start`: Starts an already provisioned node.
* `stop`: Stops an already started node.

**Implementation note**: None of these commands should rely on the actor system and instead run the commands in the main Rally process.

### Provisioning

This covers all steps from retrieving the binary (either download or build it via Gradle) until a fully configured node is installed. Note that there are essentially no new steps, it's just that we expose this now as a dedicated subcommand. One tricky aspect is that we are currently able to create a unique node name by increasing a counter (`rally-node-{N}`), see also: 

https://github.com/elastic/rally/blob/f575790902afd18e9cdd17028102724994142d35/esrally/mechanic/mechanic.py#L178-L186)

This will not be possible anymore with the `provision` subcommand as it does not have a global view of the cluster but rather a per-node view.

**Post condition**

After the provisioner has (successfully) run the following conditions are met:

* An Elasticsearch node is installed in a well-known directory `~/.rally/benchmarks/nodes/$ID/install` where `$ID` is a globally unique id generated by the provisioner.
* A meta-data file has been written to `~/.rally/benchmarks/nodes/$ID/provisioner.json` which contains the necessary data that needs to be exchanged between the provisioner and the launcher (see `NodeConfiguration` for data that are exchanged between those two).
* `$ID` is written to stdout. This id can then be used later on to start and stop this node.

**Note**: It might make sense that we specify all telemetry devices as part of the provisioning process regardless when they get attached (some are only attached on launch) and exchange the necessary information via the provisioner metadata.

### Start

This will launch a single node. The launcher process will not be a parent process of Elasticsearch (this is a change to the previous behavior) and will instead terminate once the node has successfully started. As input it will use the provisioner id to read the provisioner metadata (`NodeConfiguration`) to startup the node. Depending on the launcher type we may need to persist the PID of the Elasticsearch process. For plain vanilla Elasticsearch we might just [run it as a daemon](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/starting-elasticsearch.html#_running_as_a_daemon). Any files should go to `~/.rally/benchmarks/races/$ID` if needed.

**Post condition**

After the launcher has (successfully) run the following conditions are met:

* An Elasticsearch process is running
* Its PID is recorded in a well-known location that can be retrieved again via `$ID`.

### Stop

This will stop a node that has previously been started. If `--preserve-install=true` is specified on the command line, the node's installation and data directory will be cleaned up. Logs and telemetry data should always be kept (all of this is no change to previous behavior).

**Post condition**

* The corresponding Elasticsearch process is stopped
* All files except any telemetry data and logs have been deleted (unless `--preserve-install=true`).

### Preparatory work

As a preparation we should: 

* [x] Switch from installation directories based on the race timestamp to installation directories based on unique ids (`~/.rally/benchmarks/nodes/$ID`) - see #720
* [x] Move telemetry devices that currently rely on `ES_JAVA_OPTS` from the launcher to the provisioner and instead persist the necessary information in `config/jvm.options`. - see https://github.com/elastic/rally/pull/711
* [x] Revisit all remaining telemetry devices and ensure they will not rely on Rally being a parent process of Elasticsearch. Specifically for the `DiskIo` telemetry device we should ensure that it persists the disk counters at the beginning of a benchmark and can read it again afterwards. - see #731
* [x] Run [Elasticsearch as a daemon](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/starting-elasticsearch.html#_running_as_a_daemon) (we should do the same for the container launcher). This will simplify exposing the start command separately. - see https://github.com/elastic/rally/pull/701

### Tasks

* [x] Expose race id as command line parameter - see #778
* [x] Calculate system metrics per node - see #803
* [x] Implement `start`, `stop`and `provision` as subcommands - see #830

### Follow-up work

We will continue to support the actor-system-based approach for now but we intend to remove this coordination layer at some point and let users choose freely how they want to manage coordination (e.g. via Ansible) as this also allows for more complex setups. Doing this will require additional preparation though so we will tackle this in a separate issue.

`1.0.4`

**Invoked command**:

esrally \

--pipeline=benchmark-only \
--client-options="use_ssl:true,verify_certs:false,ca_certs:'$HOME/secret/admin-ca',client_cert:'$HOME/secret/admin-cert',client_key:'$HOME/secret/admin-key'"

**Configuration file (located in `~/.rally/rally.ini`))**:
```

**JVM version**:

OpenJDK Runtime Environment (build 1.8.0_201-b09)
OpenJDK 64-Bit Server VM (build 25.201-b09, mixed mode)
```

**OS version**:
`CentOS Linux 7 (Core)`

**Description of the problem including expected versus actual behavior**:
According to the [documentation](https://esrally.readthedocs.io/en/stable/command_line_reference.html#id2) and [code](https://github.com/elastic/rally/blob/977c0de81ed47238089a1d7169bbbdf13a47e483/esrally/utils/opts.py#L134) running Rally against external cluster should have default timeout of 60 seconds.

However, [this](https://github.com/elastic/rally/blob/master/esrally/rally.py#L628) info/debug line says otherwise, and it also seems that this exception[1] confirms it.

Solution for me was adding `timeout:60` into the `--client-options` arg.

**Steps to reproduce**:

items.title: Rally docs do not appear in search results for "rally" on ReadTheDocs
items.body:
Visit [Read the Docs](https://readthedocs.org) and [search](https://readthedocs.org/search/?q=rally) for "rally". Note that *this* Rally project does not appear in the results. I think there are a few ways that this can be fixed:
1. `esrally` [does not have a description](https://readthedocs.org/search/?q=esrally) in the search results; perhaps expand the description that includes the term `rally` as it appears the description is used in the search
2. I hesitate to propose this because of the breakage: `esrally` is actual name of the project; maybe we could change to `es-rally` for tokenization that would include the `rally` term

items.title: Show track and team revision when listing races
items.body: After implementing #664 we will have the necessary meta-data to show them also in the output of `esrally list races`. However, we should think whether we want to expose this information all the time or whether we hide it by default and only expose it if the user specifies an additional command line flag (e.g. `--verbose`).

items.title: Capture team and track revision in metrics metadata
items.body:
We already store some version info in metrics metadata:

* Elasticsearch version + revision
* JDK version
* kernel version
* Rally version

However, we do not store the track and team repository revision and we should add this as well.

**Implementation notes**

* It is possible for users to specify `--track-path` / `--team-path`. In those cases we should not track any revision because we are only referring to a plain file
* Similarly, if users are using `--pipeline=benchmark-only`, Rally does not manage the cluster thus th team-revision is not applicable.
* It will be a bit tricky to get the revisions:
    * For teams, the because is checked out on the target nodes where Elasticsearch is deployed but I think we should derive this info in `MechanicActor#receiveMsg_StartEngine()` when we are about to load the team. We then need to communicate this information back to the benchmark coordinator actor (`BenchmarkActor`) in `MechanicActor#on_cluster_started()` as an additional property in the `EngineStarted` message.
    * For tracks, we load the track in `BenchmarkActor#setup()` and can derive the revision there.

items.title: Allow to run with a specific track revision
items.body: Similarly to #625, we should introduce a new command line parameter `--track-revision` that allows users to run against an older commit of a Rally track. This is useful when testing whether a change in performance has occured due to a change in the workload.

items.title: Sort keys of track parameters and user tags when listing races
items.body:
**Describe the feature**:
When listing the races it would be nice to have the `Track Parameters` and `User Tags` sorted by key.

items.title: Include user tags when comparing two races
items.body:
**Describe the feature**:
Its useful information to include the `--user-tags` when comparing 2 races. That would give better context information to the one that reads the compare results.

Example on how it woud look like
```
# esrally compare --contender=20190227T161026Z --baseline=20190228T150825Z

    ____        ____
   / __ \____ _/ / /_  __
  / /_/ / __ `/ / / / / /
 / _, _/ /_/ / / / /_/ /
/_/ |_|\__,_/_/_/\__, /
                /____/


Comparing baseline
  Race timestamp: 2019-02-28 15:08:25
  Challenge: an-example-challenge
  Car: external
  User Tags: intention=baseline

with contender
  Race timestamp: 2019-02-27 16:10:26
  Challenge: an-example-challenge
  Car: external
  User Tags: intention=with_xyz_config
```

items.title: Creating offset file takes a very long time
items.body:
We have a jsonl file with ~1.5 lines, each line has a lot of characters (big JSONs). Running esrally starts with creating the offset file but that step takes a very very long time. During that time, we observe a very low CPU usage by esrally in a single core (usually 1-2%).

This happens on AWS and a SSD drive with provisioned IOPS.

For now we create a snapshot right after the offset file has been written, but why is this needed and why is it taking so long?

items.title: Proxy connections requiring authentication are failing
items.body:
**Rally version** (get with `esrally --version`): 1.0.3

**Steps to reproduce**:
 1. Setup an HTTP proxy server that requires authentication
 2. `export http_proxy=http://username:pw@1.2.3.4:8080`
 3. Invoke Rally

**Expected behavior**: 

Rally uses the proxy to connect to the Internet

**Actual behavior**: 

Rally reports that no Internet connection is available. On the command line we can see.

```
[WARNING] No Internet connection detected. Automatic download of track data sets etc. is disabled. 
```

**Provide logs (if relevant)**:

```
2019-01-23 15:19:43,262 -not-actor-/PID:16740 esrally.utils.net INFO Rally connects via proxy URL [http://username:pw@1.2.3.4:8080] to the Internet (picked up from the environment variable [http_proxy]).
2019-01-23 15:19:43,263 -not-actor-/PID:16740 esrally.utils.net DEBUG Checking for internet connection against [https://github.com/]
2019-01-23 15:19:43,347 -not-actor-/PID:16740 esrally.utils.net DEBUG Could not detect a working Internet connection
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/python3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/urllib3/connectionpool.py", line 595, in urlopen
    self._prepare_proxy(conn)
  File "/usr/local/python3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/urllib3/connectionpool.py", line 816, in _prepare_proxy
    conn.connect()
  File "/usr/local/python3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/urllib3/connection.py", line 294, in connect
    self._tunnel()
  File "/usr/local/python3/lib/python3.6/http/client.py", line 919, in _tunnel
    message.strip()))
OSError: Tunnel connection failed: 407 Proxy Authentication Required
```

**Analysis**:

The problem is that Python does not take the provided credentials in the URL into account. Thus, Rally needs to provide them separately using a [ProxyBasicAuthHandler](https://docs.python.org/3/library/urllib.request.html#urllib.request.ProxyBasicAuthHandler).

items.title: Add new telemetry device: recovery-stats
items.body:
We need a new telemetry device that can collect the data available in `_recovery`, see [docs](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/indices-recovery.html).

The `_recovery` stats somewhat resemble the structure of [ccr stats](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/ccr-get-stats.html) i.e. using the form

```
{
  "index1" : {
    "shards" : [ {
      "id" : 0,
      "type" : "SNAPSHOT",
      "stage" : "INDEX",
```

(note however that ccr stats looks like:
```
"follow_stats" : {
    "indices" : [
      {
        "index" : "follower_index",
        "shards" : [
          {
            "remote_cluster" : "remote_cluster",
            ...
```

so the ccr stats telemetry device code can't be used as is)

It would be great if we can also support a telemetry device option for `detailed: true` as described in the [_recovery docs](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/indices-recovery.html).

Debian

RUN pip3 install esrally
RUN apt update && apt install -y default-jdk

```
**Description of the problem including expected versus actual behavior**:
Using metric store as elasticsearch cluster backed by self-signed certificate does not work - there is no option to specify verification_mode or ca so getting an error

**Describe the feature**:
Ability to add CA and verification_mode for reporting elasticsearch cluster similar to client-options json : 
```

"ca_certs": "/home/es-rally/ca.crt"
```

items.title: Esrallyd Benchmark Candidates should not be restricted to Elasticsearch targethosts
items.body: Currently attempting to run rally cluster through `esrallyd` in a docker-compose cluster. I would like to run rally against a pre-existing Elasticsearch cluster that is not currently living on the same host as `esrallyd`. The usage of `--targethost` on the benchmark coordinator is preventing me from distributing workloads to the benchmark candidates.

items.title: Add configurable "sleep" operation
items.body: When running benchmarks against nodes that are expected to see few but long-running queries it is possible to combine request timeout with `target-interval` to ensure there is a bit of quiet time between queries. This however results in a longer quiet time for queries that return quickly. It would be useful to have an operation that just adds a configurable pause to the track so that the same quiet time can be achieved no matter how fast the query returns.

items.title: Add "hits" to a query run report
items.body: As often times there is high correlation between the total number of results matched by a query and the query latency, it'd be very useful to have a "hits" metric in the summary report for each query summary.

items.title: index-append's "error rate" counts failed shard bulk operations instead of record
items.body:
After executing a track with 60mln documents I got the report from rally with error rate of 14.68% after examination of the index, it looks like only 8701 records failed, that would roughly correspond to the number of the failed shard requests - 60,000,000 * 0.1468 / 1000 = 8,808  (I have 5 shards and the bulk size is 5000, which means from each shard bulk size is approximately 1000).

To reproduce:
- take any track with test set of 1k documents  
- modify one documents to fail during indexing
- execute rally with ---test-mode flag
Expected result
- since only 1 record out of 1000 failed, error rate should be 0.1%
Actual result:
- the error rate is 12.5%

items.title: Add total merges and refreshes in summary output
items.body:
Currently our summary output includes sections like:

```
|   All |                   Total refresh time |                            |   131.531 |    min |
|   All |           Min refresh time per shard |                            |   43.0791 |    min |
|   All |        Median refresh time per shard |                            |   44.0437 |    min |
|   All |           Max refresh time per shard |                            |   44.4079 |    min |
```

i.e. only times not count.

Given #608 we can't rely too much on node-stats atm, so makes sense to also present the `Total refreshes` / `Total merges` (maybe an avg rate too based on total time?)

items.title: Extract total hits as either structured object or number
Should not log passwords in cmd line arguments
items.body:
**Rally version** (get with `esrally --version`): 1.0.2

**Description of the problem including expected versus actual behavior**:

Similar to not logging clear text passwords in https://github.com/elastic/rally/pull/464 it would be great to have an option to not log passwords in clear that come from with the command line arguments.

```
In the `Command line arguments` the passwords are human readable. 
2018-11-22 10:05:44,492 -not-actor-/PID:1 esrally.rally INFO Rally version [1.0.2] 
2018-11-22 10:05:44,492 -not-actor-/PID:1 esrally.rally INFO Command line arguments: Namespace(advanced_config=False, assume_defaults=False, car='defaults', car_params='', challenge=None, client_options="retry_on_timeout:true,timeout:60,use_ssl:true,verify_certs:false,basic_auth_user:'user01',basic_auth_password:'password01'", .... 
```

In further logging entries the password is masked:

```
2018-11-22 10:05:45,308 ActorAddr-(T|:35550)/PID:13 esrally.client INFO Creating ES client connected to [{'host': '8.8.8.8', 'port': 9200, 'use_ssl': True}, {'host': '8.8.8.8', 'port': 9200, 'use_ssl': True}] with options [{'retry_on_timeout': True, 'timeout': 60, 'use_ssl': True, 'verify_certs': False, 'basic_auth_user': 'user01', 'basic_auth_password': '*****'}] 
```

**Describe the feature**:

Suppress or mask the clear text passwords from cmd line arguments.

items.title: Warn when enabling node-stats
items.body: When `docs` / `completion` is requested via node stats (which is done by the node stats telemetry device) it will trigger additional refreshes in Elasticsearch which will skew results and highly likely make benchmark results invalid. We should document that and maybe even emit a warning when the node stats telemetry device is turned on.

items.title: Provide a Rally docker image
items.body: In some environments it is troublesome to install all of Rally's dependencies. We should therefore provide a Docker image for Rally during the release process. One aspect that we can also address in a later release are use cases which involve the Rally daemon, like load test drivers that are distributed.

items.title: Update rally-* index templates for ES 7.0
items.body:
Rally defines default index templates for the index patterns `rally-metrics-*`, `rally-races-*` and `rally-results-*` in the resources directory of the source tree. When using an ES 6.x metrics store we get the following warnings:

```
Deprecated field [template] used, replaced by [index_patterns]
```

```
[_all] is deprecated in 6.0+ and will be removed in 7.0. As a replacement, you can use [copy_to] on mapping fields to create your own catch all field.
```

```
[_default_] mapping is deprecated since it is not useful anymore now that indexes cannot have more than one type
```

To be compatible with 7.0, we should change the mappings that Rally provides out of the box.

We should also switch the (sole) type for all indices to `_doc` as recommended in the [Elasticsearch docs](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/6.5/removal-of-types.html).

items.title: Start time-based schedules lazily
items.body:
We see `ExecutorTests#test_execute_schedule_throughput_throttled()` fail occassionally with:

```
            self.assertTrue(lower_bound <= sample_size <= upper_bound,
>                           msg="Expected sample size to be between %d and %d but was %d" % (lower_bound, upper_bound, sample_size))
E           AssertionError: False is not true : Expected sample size to be between 245 and 255 but was 244
```

 I think the reason for that failure is a timing issue. It is using a time-based schedule under the hood and the problem is that the schedule starts as soon as it is created:

https://github.com/elastic/rally/blob/1db123c446f28d8254010ed51db67a83cd3769f7/esrally/driver/driver.py#L1279

instead, it should start when the executor pulls the first item (i.e. lazily instead of eagerly). 

As this is incorrect but will not cause major problems in real life, I'm putting it in the backlog.
